com.javax0.jdsl.analyzers

Class NullAnalyzer

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.javax0.jdsl.analyzers.NullAnalyzer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Analyzer, Rule

    public class NullAnalyzer
extends Object
implements Rule
    The NullAnalyzer does not analyze anything. It ignores the source code it gets as argument to the method analyze(SourceCode). What it does is that it executes the Closure.exec(SourceCode) method of the object that is passed to the constructor (which is private anyway) when the analyzer is created.

    The intended use of the analyzer is to statically import the exec(Closure) method into the GrammarDefinition and use that to have some code to be executed at certain point. That certain point is usually in a list or alternative analyzers in the argument list of a call to the methods like GrammarDefinition.list(Analyzer...) or GrammarDefinition.oneOf(Analyzer...).

    The NullAnalyzer returns successful result and the state it returns is the one returned by the closure. Even though the return value is a successful result it can be used as argument to GrammarDefinition.oneOf(Analyzer...) or GrammarDefinition.or(Analyzer...), because the AlternativesAnalyzer these methods call recognizes that the result was coming from a NullAnalyzer and ignores the result. IN this case any state generated by the execution is also lost.

    Author:
    Peter Verhas
